newsitem.title: UK: Palladium rises again, other precious metals firm.
newsitem.headline: Palladium rises again, other precious metals firm.

text.p: The price of palladium crawled back up again on Friday as some traders began to doubt whether Russia would be able to resume exports soon.
The price had dropped on Thursday on news that a Moscow official said that a decree that should enable delayed sales to resume to Japan, the biggest importer, would be signed next week.

Gold was fixed higher at $348.65 an ounce from Thursday's $347.60 with the focus shifting to the activity of shorts before an options expiry on the New York Comex market and the U.S. Producer Price Index at 1230 GMT.
"Some evidence of increasing price pressure in the U.S. would be taken as being positive for the precious metals," one analyst said.
Dealers noted some buying emanating out of Switzerland.

"Once we get past the Comex expiration I think it will be interesting to see what takes place. I have a feeling that we'll probably see gold break out of this very restrictive range," said one London dealer, adding that upside potential was capped.
Palladium, mainly used in electronics and autocatalysts, was borrowed heavily in Europe, pushing the one-month lease rates back up to double-digit figures from about nine percent.
"The tightness is still there," said the dealer, adding that liquidation by some long holders had exacerbated a squeeze as less of that metal was now available for short-term lease.
"The gamblers' money will go on a five buck rally again."
Palladium stood $2.75 up at $158.50/159.50 an ounce at 1045 GMT, but fought shy of Thursday's 21-month high fix of $160.25.
Even so wide price gyrations were expected to continue until there was final proof that Russian exports would resume.
"Then it could fall dramatically in a major downward move and I would not be surprised to see $130-$140," one technical analyst said, forecasting a range of $153-$158 for today.
The rare white metal tumbled $5.00 on Thursday on news Russia would sign a long-awaited decree on exports, paving the way for shipments to begin in May after a four-month delay.
Its sister metal platinum spiked $3.50 up to $372.50 on Friday, a move analysts said was justified by constructive charts and the fact that prices held even as palladium fell.
Silver was firm at $4.79/$4.81 with little options-related activity expected as open interest was clustered above $5.00.

But with neither gold or silver responding to the heat generated by palladium, a move towards $4.65 support -- the April 3 low -- to suck in buying momentum might be necessary before a positive move was attempted, analysts said.
Gold could gravitate towards a test of $345.00. This was supported by technical indicators weakening slightly this week suggesting a test of support was to be expected.
